epaphras_faith

This thread is a corrolary to the thread "what gives something value?"
 
 What makes us valuable, individually?
J_ha
Well I already answered this in the other thread.
Adept

It depends. If you believe in a cosmic purpose for life, or something similar (Like the bible I suppose) then that gives people value.
 
 If you do not believe in a cosmic purpose, then the individual must decide the value of people by himself.
 
 It is my opinion that since (at this stage) theories on cosmic purpose and value are mere thoughts lacking any kind of solid proof (And no, personal testimony, in any form, does not count), it is foolish to hold to them.
epaphras_faith

It depends. If you believe in a cosmic purpose for life, or something similar (Like the bible I suppose) then that gives people value.
 
 If you do not believe in a cosmic purpose, then the individual must decide the value of people by himself.
 
 It is my opinion that since (at this stage) theories on cosmic purpose and value are mere thoughts lacking any kind of solid proof (And no, personal testimony, in any form, does not count), it is foolish to hold to them.

 
 Therefore, you would claim that no one has any inherent value. This allows you to determine other's value and if they are of no value to dispose of them or their feelings as you see fit. Handy that. emoticon_wow
Adept

Therefore, you would claim that no one has any inherent value. This allows you to determine other's value and if they are of no value to dispose of them or their feelings as you see fit. Handy that. emoticon_wow

 
 emoticon_smile 
 
 Actually, it is. However, before you get all high and mighty, answer me a few questions:
 
 1 - If your wife (Or similar loved one) and a known serial killer/rapist are both drowning, and you can only save one, who will it be?
 
 2 - Did you ever have a loved pet (A puppy or a kitten, or something)? If you did, when it died did you feel more or less upset than when those people were killed in the Iranian earthquake a few weeks ago? Answer honestly now...
 
 I'm not going to both trying to trip you up and tricking you, I'm going to cut to the chase. Either the value of all people is set in stone, and is equal, or it is completely subjective. I do no believe there is any evidence to support the claims that it is equal and objective, hence I believe it is purely subjective. If you would rather save your wife or loved one than a rapist or serial killer, then you obviously believe that your wife is more important. Or at least more important to you. Which means to a certain extent you have made a value judgement on the other person, and determined that their value is less than your wifes.
 
 The second question is similar. I cried when my pets had to be put down, I surely did. I loved them dearly, and it was hard to see them go. However, when the Iranian earthquake hit, I was slightly despondent for a few minutes, then I changed the channel and watched the simpsons. Those people meant nothing to me, and apart from a breif pang of empathic sympathy, I did not care for their loss. In fact, very few people did. If you honestly value each life equally, then you must mourn each passing life equally also. Each murder, each accident victim, all across the globe. Would you mourn if your parents died? What about if four people in China were killed by a falling tree and you heard it on the news? Would you feel twice as bad? Why or why not?
 
 Once it is all boiled down, and all the philosophical rhetoric is scooped off the top, the only value that people have is that set by their peers. It is subjective, not objective.
epaphras_faith

 First, cut the rhetoric (high and mighty emoticon_rolleyes ). Second, I will be happy to answer your questions in a moment. I want to say that it is irrelvant as to what I choose. I do not determine the value of an individual from an objective standpoint. I cannot. I did not make that individual. I do often determine the value of people relative to me. Much to my shame. Just because I engage in it (or you) does not make it right or correct. There is still the objective reality that people have inherent value.
 
 Now, I would like for us to be more civil so I will tone down my rhetoric if you will yours. Also, have you looked at the previously mentioned thread. See what others (and I) have said about the value of things. Then let us discuss this in more depth. 
 
 Also, I would like to know on what you base your assumptions that none has value. Right now you are saying that you get to determine that. Why?
Adept

First, cut the rhetoric (high and mighty emoticon_rolleyes ). Second, I will be happy to answer your questions in a moment. I want to say that it is irrelvant as to what I choose. I do not determine the value of an individual from an objective standpoint. I cannot. I did not make that individual. I do often determine the value of people relative to me. Much to my shame. Just because I engage in it (or you) does not make it right or correct. There is still the objective reality that people have inherent value.

 
 There is still an objective reality? Show it to me. I want to see the evidence from which you draw your conclusion. From my own research, and that of others, I have been unable to find any evidence which supports your position. If you cannot find any evidence, yet continue to maintain this position, then I am afraid I must end the conversation, as there will be nothing I can say to convince you.
 
 
Now, I would like for us to be more civil so I will tone down my rhetoric if you will yours. Also, have you looked at the previously mentioned thread. See what others (and I) have said about the value of things. Then let us discuss this in more depth. 

 
 I did not believe I was being over-rhetorical, or arrogant. My apologies if I came across as such. I have read the other thread, and have posted in it.
 
 
Also, I would like to know on what you base your assumptions that none has value. Right now you are saying that you get to determine that. Why?

 
 I am saying that I see no reason to believe that an objective value for humans exists. Why should I believe we are all equally valuable, if there is no reason for me to do so? I am saying I get to decide how valuable I think people are. I am also saying that this is the only kind of value anyone can have. If all life is valued equally, how can we have murderers and the death penalty? How can we justify war? How can we justify collateral damage and the like? What about justifiable homicide? I bring these examples up because these are all real-life situations where taking life is considered justifiable. If it can be justifiable, how can it at the same time have an objective value?
XeoX

An objective reality may exist.
 Objective value does not.
 The concept 'value' is an abstract human invention and the only way to measure it is in your own mind.

 You say it is all subjective. There are things that will occur no matter what. Would you agree with that?

 
 When I mentioned 'objective reality' above, I was referring to the comment: 'There is an objective reality that people have an inherent value'.
 
 But yes, as I believe it is impossible to alter the course of the future, then I do believe that things will occur no matter what. I say that value is subjective.
epaphras_faith

When I mentioned 'objective reality' above, I was referring to the comment: 'There is an objective reality that people have an inherent value'.
 
 But yes, as I believe it is impossible to alter the course of the future, then I do believe that things will occur no matter what. I say that value is subjective.

 
 Very well. Is that not objective. You say the future is set. That sounds suspiciously like a standard.
 
 Here is one. You and I will die. It cannot be stopped. It will happen. This is real. I started a similar thread in the philosophy thread concerning what is truth. That is corallary to this. See what you think.
 
 Objective is simply that something is what it is regardless of the observer. Would you agree with that definition. (I promise I will get back to the value of people question shortly, please continue to indulge my questions).

Very well. Is that not objective. You say the future is set. That sounds suspiciously like a standard.

 
 Standard? In what way?
 
 
Here is one. You and I will die. It cannot be stopped. It will happen. This is real. I started a similar thread in the philosophy thread concerning what is truth. That is corallary to this. See what you think.

 
 Actually, our death is not certain. With advances in cryogenic freezing, hormone replacement therapy and gene manipulation it is quite concievable that death from natural causes could become a thing of the past within our lifetimes. But thats not the point.
 
 
Objective is simply that something is what it is regardless of the observer. Would you agree with that definition. (I promise I will get back to the value of people question shortly, please continue to indulge my questions).

 
 ob·jec·tive ( P ) Pronunciation Key (b-jktv)
 adj. 
 1 Of or having to do with a material object. 
 2 Having actual existence or reality. 
 3 - Uninfluenced by emotions or personal prejudices: an objective critic. See Synonyms at fair1. 
 - Based on observable phenomena; presented factually: an objective appraisal. 
 
 From this, I would conclude that (in relation to moral value) something that is objective is something that exists as an actual, existant constant. It would be constant no matter the opinions or prejudices of the viewer.
epaphras_faith

Standard? In what way?
 
 
 
 Actually, our death is not certain. With advances in cryogenic freezing, hormone replacement therapy and gene manipulation it is quite concievable that death from natural causes could become a thing of the past within our lifetimes. But thats not the point.

 2 Having actual existence or reality. 
 3 - Uninfluenced by emotions or personal prejudices: an objective critic. See Synonyms at fair1. 
 - Based on observable phenomena; presented factually: an objective appraisal. 
 
 From this, I would conclude that (in relation to moral value) something that is objective is something that exists as an actual, existant constant. It would be constant no matter the opinions or prejudices of the viewer.

 
 To say the future is not set. Is an absolute statement. I could compare everything about the future against that statement. If one instance is found wrong your assumption is wrong. You are engaging in fanciful thinking to say that death could disappear within our lifetime. I think you know better and are simply trying to prove your point. Be realistic. You will die. 
 
 Your definition of objective is reasonably accurate. The idea I was trying to convey was the one on being consistent.
 
 Next, do you believe there are absolutes?

To say the future is not set. Is an absolute statement. I could compare everything about the future against that statement. If one instance is found wrong your assumption is wrong. 

 
 I'm not sure what you are trying to say here. My belief is that the future is set through cause and effect. One cannot change it. There is no free will. But this really belongs in the free will vs. determinism thread.
 
 
You are engaging in fanciful thinking to say that death could disappear within our lifetime. I think you know better and are simply trying to prove your point. Be realistic. You will die. 

 
 Its more than likely, but not certain. 
 
 
Next, do you believe there are absolutes?

However, it is my belief that a rock will always be a rock, no matter your frame of reference. This is a belief supported by all the evidence I have thus far seen.

 For your first paragraph, I was answering to you about how it was a standard. Death is certain. There are only two that have not died and one who died but lives. At least biblically speaking. Enoch, Elisha and Jesus respectively. If you don't accept the bible then none whatsoever. All have died. It is a certainty. There is no evidence that currently exists that death can be prevented, life prolonged for a bit perhaps, but zero evidence to support the claim that death can be prevented. But this is really an aside.
 
 You seem to accept the idea that there are absolutes. Good. Even if only physical items. I will accept that.
 
 Please continue to indulge me. You will likely see where I am going and in a few more questions I promise to relate it to the topic.
 
 Do you believe in truth? An absolute truth? Are there things that are true no matter what you believe or say?

 Actually, there are many creatures in the natural world who have the ability to re-generate, most notably starfish and axolotls. Death by natural causes comes about as the cells in the body cease to re-produce, and the body begins to deteriorate. It is quite feasable to copy these genes into the human body, and find out where the switch is which turns off the ability to regenerate. It is possible to thereofore eliminate death by natural causes. 
 
 
Please continue to indulge me. You will likely see where I am going and in a few more questions I promise to relate it to the topic.
 
 Do you believe in truth? An absolute truth? Are there things that are true no matter what you believe or say?

 
 It depends. Things like personal opinion (That is a beautiful painting) or (What a lovely day) are not truth. They are opinion, which is different. Truth is a difficult thing to pin down like this, as it is often very relative. Stone is hard. That could be considered a truth. However, stone is not hard compared to Diamond. Therefore it could be considered a lie.
 
 To answer the question, then yes. There are some things that are objectively true. Some things like mathematics, atomic weights, and various other physical properties. I do not believe that this extends, in any way shape or form, to mental constructs and opinions.
epaphras_faith

Actually, there are many creatures in the natural world who have the ability to re-generate, most notably starfish and axolotls. It is possible to thereofore eliminate death by natural causes.

Therefore it could be considered a lie.
 
 To answer the question, then yes. There are some things that are objectively true. Some things like mathematics, atomic weights, and various other physical properties. I do not believe that this extends, in any way shape or form, to mental constructs and opinions.

 
 Let us put aside the issue of death as it is academic to the discussion. I agree that opinions are not truth. 
 
 As for mental constructs, I would submit that truth is the lining up of reality with what is said. (I have this on a thread called "what is truth" by the way.)
 
 I have said that to say that the gas tank is full is true only if the gas tank is full. Others have said that if I believe the gas tank is full then to say it is true. I state that it is only true if the tank is actually full.
 
 What do you think?
Adept

I have said that to say that the gas tank is full is true only if the gas tank is full. Others have said that if I believe the gas tank is full then to say it is true. I state that it is only true if the tank is actually full.
 
 What do you think?

 
 I believe that it is true to say the gas tank is full, only if it is actually full. And full is a relative term, which would need defining. Are we talking about 100% full? or just greater than 80% full? Or full of air? Or Fuel? Or Water? Or anything else? Objectively, the tank is always full of something, unless it has a vacuum inside it.
 
 However, I assume we are talking about fuel inside a fuel tank. In which case, it must be full for it to be true to say it is full. You may believe it to be full, and claim it as the truth, but that does not make it full. The problem with this analogy is that it deals with a physical entity. It is easily measured, and the truth of the matter ascertained. Next question?

 It has become very clear to me why you think no one has value. Objective value that is. To you, people only have value for you to use them. It is purely subjective to you. There is no reality beyond yourself.
 
 I am not saying these things as insults. This is what I think you believe. Is it a poor characterization?
Adept

It has become very clear to me why you think no one has value. Objective value that is. To you, people only have value for you to use them. It is purely subjective to you. There is no reality beyond yourself.
 
 I am not saying these things as insults. This is what I think you believe. Is it a poor characterization?

 
 Thats pretty much accurate, except for the bit I highlighted in bold. People do not only have value for me to use them. I value people for other reasons also.
fish3

"If it does not have a tangible, measurable and comparable substance, then it exists solely in the realm of thought and opinion, which is purely subjective." -Adept
 
 That is a self-refuting statement. You cannot create your own absolute truth in order to argue that there are none. If everything (non-physical) is subjective, then why are you arguing? Why do you speak at all if everything you say is subjective?
epaphras_faith

Thats pretty much accurate, except for the bit I highlighted in bold. People do not only have value for me to use them. I value people for other reasons also.

 
 Really, you stated a bit earlier, "I am saying I get to decide how valuable I think people are. " and then , "I am saying that I see no reason to believe that an objective value for humans exists." and again, "the only value that people have is that set by their peers. It is subjective, not objective."
 
 If you get to decide, and there is no "objective" value then you would have to decide based on what they can do for you. If, for you, people only have what value YOU put on them, then YOU are the center of your universe, and people would necessarily have a utilitarian purpose.
 
 Do you see my point?
Adept

Do you see my point?

 
 
 Oh yes, I see your point. And strictly speaking I suppose it is true. It is more of a language inflection issue. When you say people only have value for me to use them, it translates to me as if I only value people that I can use. When I talk about using someone, I mean the process by which you manipulate them to achieve your own goals with no regard to them or their well being.
 
 This is not how I treat people, and not the only requirement for me to value a person.
 
 It is true that I only value people to the extent that they enrich my life, but the ways in which they do that are many, varied, and very different.
 
 So yes, I understand what you are saying, I interpreted it in a different way is all.
Adept

"If it does not have a tangible, measurable and comparable substance, then it exists solely in the realm of thought and opinion, which is purely subjective." -Adept
 
 That is a self-refuting statement. You cannot create your own absolute truth in order to argue that there are none. If everything (non-physical) is subjective, then why are you arguing? Why do you speak at all if everything you say is subjective?

 
 emoticon_rolleyes
 
 Very well.
 
 If it does not have a tangible, measurable and comparable substance, then  all the evidence curently available to us indicates that it exists solely in the realm of thought and opinion, which is purely subjective. There is currently no evidence to the contrary.
 
 Bits in bold added for technical correctness. Happy now?
 
 With regards to motivation in terms of subjectivity: Why not? I am arguing because it pleases me to do so. I speak because it pleases me to do so. Or the alternatives are less pleasing, whatever. I do this, because of all the available options, this one is the one I am best pleased with.

When I talk about using someone, I mean the process by which you manipulate them to achieve your own goals with no regard to them or their well being.
 
 This is not how I treat people, and not the only requirement for me to value a person.
 
 It is true that I only value people to the extent that they enrich my life, but the ways in which they do that are many, varied, and very different.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  What gives a person value?
